title: Can We Have a Serious Discussion About ARAM "Random"ness???
body:
So tired of getting matchups like this in ARAM (my team was the Nami).

It seems like more and more games in ARAM as of late have been completely one-sided. In the example given above, we would try to initiate on the enemy team (once we hit 6) and they just kited backwards every time. They had us constantly pushed to turret (via Heimer, AP Janna, and Caitlyn Q), they constantly poked at us (like playing a bullet hell game, if I wanted that I'd play Touhou).

There's also the fact that, in blind pick, you can have the same champion on both teams (the dreaded mirror matchup). Since ARAM is Blind Pick, if it were truly random, there would be mirror matchups from time to time. Not only have I never seen an ARAM mirror matchup, but neither have ANY of the people I have spoken with about the matter.

Add in the number of times that I've rerolled a champion, only to see it on the other team when the game starts up, and I get the feeling that a pool of ~20 or so champions are picked prior to the champ select starting, the dishing out the champions from there. With the number of OBSCENELY one sided games I've seen, I'd also say it "randomly" places the champions on their teams based on synergy (at least to some extent).

Everything I've seen thus far completely dissuades me from trying to play another ARAM, because it honestly makes me feel like Riot has determined which team should win, and then 5 people are lucky before the game even starts. This doesn't make for even a remotely fun game in, what should be, a "specifically for fun" game mode.

Anyone else have thoughts on this?

Also: Leona

I've been playing ARAM a lot lately and this struck me as well. To be fair, I don't really have many champions (roughly ~25) but I always get the same Varus, Annie, Tristana or Lulu. Not that they are bad, but I get them many times **in a row**, Annie being the most frequent one. 

Every once in a while I get someone different, maybe from the rotation, but then I'm back to the fantastic four.

I own nearly every champion in the game. Suffice it to say, I should never (theoretically the chances are astonishingly low) get doubles.

The other day I played four total ARAMs, and two total champs. (Mundo in game 1 and 2, and someone else that I don't like in games 3 and 4.)

Just because its unlikely doesn't mean it shouldn't or won't happen. When you give it enough chances the improbable becomes probable. Not to mention when an outlying situation like this occurs it stands out to us, but when it doesn't occur we don't even think twice. To say you should never get doubles is logically flawed.

I'm not saying it should never happen (note the parenthesis in the previous post).

What I'm saying is, the amount of times it DOES happen is FAR greater than it, even remotely, should be.

Arams feel like the winning team is decided before the match even begins. One team has global spells and auto attacks, and the other team gets three shot under the tower. Unless you're a hive mind, as the melee team, your engages will never be in sync. Somebody always dives in 1v5 before a fight even starts. The amount of times I've come back from a melee V.S ranged match can be counted on one hand.
Make all champions free in ARAM, stops the rigging and makes the gamemode focus on fun as it should.

Also has the advantage of making it inacessible to anyone who haven't tried out every single champion.

New players aren't going to jump into aram because they don't even know what it stands for, let alone how it works. If you want to make the argument that it's unfair because you might not know the champion, than the opposite is true. What happens when a player gets their main champion in aram, is that fair to the other team? When you allow accounts with 10 champions only to play in a gamemode where balance isn't enforced properly, you ruin the whole point of the gamemode. It's ALL RANDOM ALL MID. Owning 10 op aram champions only isn't random, and makes for terribly one sided games.

The best solution is to stay true to the concept of aram. Everyone gets a random champion, regardless if they know how to play it or not, and not based on the champions they own. The games will be WAY more balanced because both team will probably end up with players playing champions they don't know. Aram isn't a learning ground, it isn't a tutorial, and I wouldn't recommend it to new players.

ARAM is the only thing I really play. I wish the champion selection were anything like random. I have ninety-something champions, and there are about a dozen of them that I see ten times more than all the others. I just find it annoying, but from the standpoint of people who have to play against me, it's sort of unfair. I'm almost always the top score in my games, and that wouldn't happen so much if I was forced to play all of my champions equally, instead of constantly being handed someone I've already played twice in the last five games.

I don't see any reason to think it isn't random and I own all champions. You have to consider other factors that affect what champions you will get such as the other players champion pools and free week champs. Also if you are anything like me, people tend to reroll the champions they don't really feel like playing or trade them away for someone else to roll. Also some people don't think about what the definition of random is. You can get the same champ 1000 times in a row and it can still be called random. Random is quote: "proceeding, made, or occurring without definite aim, reason, or pattern". You could never see a champion for the rest of your life and it could still be called random.
I've noticed that I tend to get a lot of the same champions over and over in ARAM.  Maybe it's random but I swear sometimes it feels rigged.  Probably something to do with aram only accounts.
